newsitem.title: UK: British kids choose tans over being thin - survey.
newsitem.headline: British kids choose tans over being thin - survey.

text.p: British children, already showing what many parents and doctors think is an unhealthy obsession with being thin, think it's even more important to have a suntan, a poll published on Thursday has found.
A poll commissioned for the Cancer Research Campaign charity found that that 58 percent of eight to 10-year-olds surveyed thought people looked better with a tan.
Only 41 percent said they thought being thin was attractive.

The MORI poll of 413 children found children in the cooler north of Britain were more likely to value a tan. Most dermatologists say any kind of a tan indicates skin has been damaged by the sun and say seeking a tan is dangerous.
"Unless attitudes change, skin cancer could overtake anorexia as the biggest new threat to our children in the next decades," said Gordon McVie, the charity's director-general.

"Our survey shows that 40 percent of the young children we spoke to have already been burned at least once. And of those, around a quarter said that they had been sunburned on at least three separate occasions," McVie added.
"Experts believe that it takes only six bouts of sunburn during a lifetime to double the risk of developing skin cancer."
